```haskell
fibonacci :: Integral a => a -> a
fibonacci nth
  | n == 0    = 0
  | n < 3     = 1
  | otherwise = fibonacci (nth - 1) + fibonacci (nth - 2)
  where n = abs nth
```

From the article: "I would never have arrived at where I’m at if I hadn’t started tinkering around with my AIM profile in the first place and celebrated the small wins. I’ve realized that learning to program is a long journey and one that is different for everyone. But if you start, continue to tinker and test things out, and appreciate the moments in which things work, you’ll find it a lot easier to keep pushing forward."
Give this a quick read. I think it's very encouraging! We have to celebrate the small wins! http://blog.thefirehoseproject.com/posts/7-minutes-programming-advice-13-year-old-self/
I've felt some of these things too. Lately the more I learn the more things seem the same and the more aware of what I'm lacking I become.

@SPHornsby I'm just about to start the job hunt although I don't feel even close to ready and I'm suffering  highly from "imposter syndrome". 

From my experiance Ruby/Rails has been pleasent for the most part. I think it's reputation as a programer friendly language, framework and community is definately true altough I can't say with certainty as I don't have much context outside of it. 

In regard to bootcamp, I'm very happy that I made the decision to attend and had a good experiance overall at the camp that I chose, but I cant help having mixed feelings about it for 2 reasons.

1. Time. Leaning to program is going to take time (more than "x weeks") .There is no way around it and I think sometimes people feel/see a bootcamp as shortcut to the finish line when of course it's just the beggining of a long journey. I feel like that realization was crucial for my feelings as I neared the end of my camp experiance still feeling a bit lost and like a complete noob.

2. Cost. I really think you can learn most of what bootcamps seem to teach on your own (with a littl bit of effort of course) free or at little cost. There are a ton of great resources like Free Code Camp and The Pragmatic Studio for Ruby/Rails (https://pragmaticstudio.com) that in my opinion do as good of a job and better in some cases covering core dev topics. 

What has your experience been like?

```js
var createCounter = seed => ({
  inc: () => seed += 1,
  dec: () => seed -= 1,
  value: () => seed
})

var counter = createCounter(10)

counter.dec()   // 9
counter.dec()   // 8
counter.inc()   // 9
counter.value() // 9
```

Hi everyone. I thought that we could add a small amount of structure to the Wednesday night meetups. What do you think about tackling stuff in this order.

1. Bootstrap newcomers by helping Install All The Things (maybe until 6:30-7ish)
2. Help newcomers add a commit to the community repo.
2. Split into an Algorithms group and an HTML5/CSS group
3. Something, something advanced JavaScript and helping with projects

This is just a rough idea. But my thinking is that it would be cool for more experienced attendees to focus on helping newcomers get started in the beginning, then get their own questions answered or just hang out.

What do you think?

##Please note that we now recommend campers use their Campsite’s Facebook group for chatting instead of their campsite’s Gitter chatroom. 
We are doing this because few of our Campsite Gitter chatroooms have active synchronous discussions, and about 1/3rd of conversations consist of someone saying “hello” and not getting a response. Most of the discussions are asynchronous, which Facebook posts and group messages are better suited for.
We’ve removed this Gitter room from our Campsite directory. Still, we will keep it open for archival purposes, and you can keep using it if you’d like.
Here’s a short blog post about how our Campsites are evolving and growing: http://blog.freecodecamp.com/2015/09/jump-start-your-local-campsite-with-coffee-and-code.html

Hi @dortiz76  Great question.  Our meetup is for those at all levels at Free Code Camp. This Saturday, we'll get a sense of how advanced everyone is and either work on bonfires or, if more advanced, look to work on a zipline. :)

Even though we were at different places in the camp we worked together on a couple problems which I thought was really fun. Learning about code wars was a good educational break from the free code camp bonfires.
If you're going through free code camp the meetup is a good event to get together and learn new tools and techniques as well as to share your knowledge with others.
